prevtext:
\begin{center} 
 {\bf\Large{A novel method to deal with off-shell particles in cascade decays}}

\vspace{0.5cm}

{\bf Joydeep Chakrabortty} $^a$\footnote{joydeep@iitk.ac.in},
{\bf Anirban Kundu} $^b$\footnote{anirban.kundu.cu@gmail.com}, 
and 
{\bf Tripurari Srivastava} $^a$\footnote{tripurar@iitk.ac.in}

$^a$ {Department of Physics, Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur-208016, India}\\
$^b$ {Department of Physics, University of Calcutta, \\
92 Acharya Prafulla Chandra Road, Kolkata 700009, India}



\end{center}


\begin{abstract}

We propose a novel algorithm to compute the width of any generic $n$-body decay 
involving multiple off-shell particles having zero and non-zero spins. Starting 
from a toy example, we show the computations for three different processes 
that contain spin-0, $\frac12$, and 1 off-shell particles. We have checked that 
our results match with the existing results at the analytical level. This proposal 
can be automatized and should be useful to compute the phase space for long cascade 
decays, without any Monte Carlo sampling.

\end{abstract}



PACS No.: {12.20.Ds, 14.80.-j, 12.90.+b}



\setcounter{footnote}{0}
\renewcommand*{{\fnsymbol{footnote}}}{\arabic{footnote}}


\section{Introduction}



A standard problem in quantum field theory is to calculate the decay width $\Gamma$ of a 
parent particle $A$ to $n$ number of daughter particles. As is well-known, the physics 
resides in the spin-averaged matrix element squared $\overline{\left\vert {\cal{M}}\right\vert^2}$ for the transition, but 
there are two kinematic factors also, namely, the initial flux (which is given by the 
mass of $A$ if it is at rest) and the $n$-body phase space. While the calculation of 
$\Gamma$ for $1\to 2$ processes is an undergraduate exercise, the phase space integration 
gets complicated for $n\geq 3$, and even more so if all the particle masses are kept 
in the calculation. Often, this has to be done by some Monte Carlo (MC) sampling \cite{calchep},
introducing further uncertainties and also taking a lot of computer time. Depending on the 
complexity of the phase space, one has to compromise between the accuracy and the computer 
time needed, even more so if a huge number of events are to be generated.  

In this paper we would like to propose an algorithmic approach to deal with the $1\to n$ cascade
decays, mediated by {\em virtual} particles. The algorithm does not work if one or more of the 
intermediate particles are on-shell; one must apply the algorithm separately for different cascade
branches. The algorithm consists of the following steps. Several examples are provided later on, 
as well as estimates of numerical accuracy of the approach. 

\begin{enumerate}
\item Cut each and every off-shell propagator into two pieces such
that the full cascade can be decomposed in terms of multiple  
$1\to 2$ decays. This is, of course, not the usual prescription of
Cutkosky \cite{cutkosky} of cutting an on-shell propagator to get the absorptive part of the 
amplitude. Rather, this is 
an artificial cut, and one must remember that the cut propagator is 
still off-shell. Thus, (i) the spin sum over the off-shell leg cannot be done at this stage, and 
(ii) the phase space becomes imaginary. 

\item Assign spin (for fermions) and polarization (for gauge bosons) indices
for all particles, both on- and off-shell. Our convention for the following examples will be 
to use Latin (Greek) alphabet for fermion (gauge boson) polarization indices. We will call both of them 
spin, as there should not be any chance of confusion.
 

\item While squaring the amplitude, one must not sum over the external leg 
spins that are off-shell, as mentioned in Rule 1. The indices that appear in the vertices 
are to be summed over as usual. Following this prescription, we calculate a few 
quantities (examples are provided later) which are analogous to the scalar 
quantities like $\overline{\left\vert {\cal{M}}\right\vert^2}$ or $\Gamma$ that one usually computes. However, 
because of the floating indices, they are not scalars in our case; rather, they are 
tensors in spin indices. 


\item Once we compute all such variables necessary for the full cascade decay,
we will club them according to their appearance in the cascade such that all the 
spin indices are contracted leading to the trace of the full matrix in spin space.
The final trace is a scalar quantity. For an off-shell scalar propagator, the entire 
trace can be decomposed into the product of two traces. 


\item The most important part is to write the $1\to 2$ phase space function in terms of the 
invariant masses of the off-shell particles and then integrate over all possible values 
of the invariant mass. 

For $n$ off-shell particles there will be $n$ such integrals. This integral takes into account the 
off-shell propagator too. This is the crux of the algorithm and should better be followed by the 
following examples.

\item
All the intermediate ``partial decay widths" ${\tilde{\Gamma}}$ are to be defined in the prescribed way. 
Their dimensions need not be that of mass. 

\item Finally, for identical particles in the final state, we need to incorporate the symmetry factor in the form of 
$(1-\frac{1}{2}\delta_{IJ})$ for the decay $A^{(*)} \to IJ$. 

\end{enumerate}
Thus, the width for the decay $A\to B^*C^*$, $B^*\to DE$, $C^*\to FG$ should typically be of the form
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Gamma=\frac{1}{m_{A}}\int\left[\frac{1}{\pi}\frac{dm_{DE}^{2}}{(m_{DE}^{2}-m_%
{B}^{2})^{2}}\right]\left[\frac{1}{\pi}\frac{dm_{FG}^{2}}{(m_{FG}^{2}-m_{C}^{2%
})^{2}}\right]{\tilde{\Gamma}}(A\to BC){\tilde{\Gamma}}(B\to DE){\tilde{\Gamma%
}}(C\to FG)\,," display="block"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>A</mi></msub></mfrac><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>π</mi></mfrac><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>E</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>E</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mi>B</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac><mo>]</mo></mrow><mrow><mo>[</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>π</mi></mfrac><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>G</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mrow><mi>F</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>G</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mi>C</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac><mo>]</mo></mrow><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>A</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>B</mi><mi>C</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>D</mi><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>C</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>F</mi><mi>G</mi><mo rspace="4.2pt" stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
which is easy to evaluate; the only thing to keep in mind is to use $m_{DE}$ instead of $m_B$ because $B$ is 
off-shell. The factor of $1/m_A$ is the flux factor evaluated in the rest frame of the parent particle. 
 If the intermediate state $B$ has a large width, we should replace
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\tilde{\Gamma}}(B\to DE)=\frac{1}{2}\int d_{PS}^{B\to DE}|{\cal M}(B\to DE)|^%
{2}\,," display="block"><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>D</mi><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msubsup><mi>d</mi><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo><mrow><mi>D</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>E</mi></mrow></mrow></msubsup><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℳ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>B</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>D</mi><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><msup><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mn>2</mn></msup></mpadded><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
which is easy to evaluate; the only thing to keep in mind is to use $m_{DE}$ instead of $m_B$ because $B$ is 
off-shell. The factor of $1/m_A$ is the flux factor evaluated in the rest frame of the parent particle. 
 If the intermediate state $B$ has a large width, we should replace

mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Gamma\left(H\to W^{-}t{\overline{}}{b}\right)=\frac{1}{m_{H}}\int\left[\frac{%
1}{\pi}\frac{dm_{12}^{2}}{(m_{12}^{2}-m_{W}^{2})^{2}}\right]\par
{\rm Tr}\left%
[\tilde{\Gamma}(H\to W^{-}W^{+*})\tilde{\Gamma}(W^{+*}\to t{\overline{}}{b})%
\right]\,." display="block"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mi>W</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><mi>t</mi><mover accent="true"><mi/><mo>¯</mo></mover><mi>b</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>H</mi></msub></mfrac><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>π</mi></mfrac><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mi>W</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac><mo>]</mo></mrow><mi>Tr</mi><mrow><mo>[</mo><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>→</mo><msup><mi>W</mi><mo>-</mo></msup><msup><mi>W</mi><mrow><mi/><mo>+</mo><mo>*</mo></mrow></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><msup><mi>W</mi><mrow><mi/><mo>+</mo><mo>*</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><mi>t</mi><mover accent="true"><mi/><mo>¯</mo></mover><mi>b</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt">]</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: Taking the parent $H$ to be at rest and using $k^2=m_{12}^2$, we get
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E6.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\sum_{\lambda}\epsilon^{*\mu}_{\lambda}(k)\epsilon^{
u}_{\lambda}(k)=-g^{\mu%

u}+ rac{k^{\mu}k^{
u}}{m_{W}^{2}}\,." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>λ</mi></munder><mrow><msubsup><mi>ϵ</mi><mi>λ</mi><mrow><mi/><mo>*</mo><mi>μ</mi></mrow></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>ϵ</mi><mi>λ</mi><mi>ν</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>k</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>g</mi><mrow><mi>μ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ν</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>k</mi><mi>μ</mi></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>k</mi><mi>ν</mi></msup></mrow><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mi>W</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mfrac></mpadded></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
where ${\cal F}$, evaluated from the spin sum and the trace, is
\begin{eqnarray} 
 {\cal F} &=& \frac{16}{m_W^4}\left[ 
 2 m_{W}^2 (p_2.p_3)(p_2.p_4) + 4 m_W^2(k.p_3)(k.p_4)
 -2 m_W^2 m_{12}^2 (p_3.p_4)-2 (k.p_2)(k.p_3)(p_2.p_4) 
 \right. \nonumber\\
 && \left. 
 - 2 (k.p_2)(k.p_4)(p_2.p_3) +  2 (k.p_2)^2(p_3.p_4) +m_{12}^4 (p_3.p_4) 
 -2 m_{12}^2 (k.p_3)(k.p_4)
 \right.\nonumber\\
 && 
 \left. + 2 m_{W}^{-2}  (k.p_2)^2(k.p_3)(k.p_4) -m_{W}^{-2} m_{12}^2 (p_3.p_4)(k.p_2)^2 + m_W^4 (p_4.p_3)\right]\,. 
\end{eqnarray}

A comparison of our method, where the integration is done numerically by {\tt Mathematica} \cite{Mathematica}, and 
the result from {\tt CalcHEP v3.6.25} \cite{calchep}, is shown in Table 1. The typical 
uncertainty in the evaluation of the decay width through Monte Carlo sampling is about 10\%, 
and our method is in complete agreement. 



\begin{table}[htbp]
\begin{center}
\begin{tabular}{ |c|c|c|}
\hline
$m_t$ & $m_H$  & $\Gamma$ \\
 (GeV) & (GeV)   & (GeV) \\
 \hline
{0}  & 82 & $2.962(2.942)\times 10^{-11}$\\

 & 125 & $2.771(2.739)\times 10^{-4}$ \\
 & 150 & $4.007(3.954)\times 10^{-3}$ \\
 \hline
{25} & 106 & $2.595(2.687) \times 10^{-10}$\\

 & 120 & $1.989(1.916)\times 10^{-5}$ \\
 & 130 & $1.478(1.419) \times 10^{-4}$\\
 \hline
{50} & 132 & $2.846(2.869)\times 10^{-8}$ \\ 
 & 140 & $1.901(1.833) \times 10^{-5}$\\
& 150 & $4.040(3.859)\times 10^{-4}$ \\ 
\hline
\end{tabular}
\caption{Decay widths for different values of $m_t$ and $m_H$. 
Central values from {\tt CalcHEP v.3.6.25} \cite{calchep} with a typical error of 10\%
are shown in parenthesis. We have taken $m_b=0$ and $V_{tb}=1$. }
\end{center}
\label{tab:hwtb}
\end{table}





\subsection{$H\to t {\overline}{t}^*$, ${\overline}{t}^*\to  {\overline}{b} W^-$}

\begin{figure}[h!]
\begin{center}
\includegraphics[width=8cm]{h_tbw.pdf}
\end{center}
\caption{Feynman diagram for $H\to t {\overline}{t}^*$, ${\overline}{t}^*\to {\overline}{b} W^-$.
}
\label{fig:htt}
\end{figure}


This is an analogous case with a fictitious heavy Higgs boson and involving an off-shell fermion. The Feynman 
diagram, including the spin and momentum labels, is shown in Fig.\ \ref{fig:htt}. Thus
prevtext: Taking the parent $H$ to be at rest and using $k^2=m_{12}^2$, we get
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Gamma(H\to Wt{\overline{}}{b})=\frac{N_{c}g^{2}m_{W}^{4}}{4m_{H}v^{2}}|V_{tb}%
|^{2}\int\left[\frac{1}{\pi}\frac{dm_{12}^{2}}{(m_{12}^{2}-m_{W}^{2})^{2}}%
\right]\int d_{PS}^{W^{*}\to t{\overline{}}{b}}\int d_{PS}^{H\to WW^{*}}{\cal F%
}\,," display="block"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>W</mi><mi>t</mi><mover accent="true"><mi/><mo>¯</mo></mover><mi>b</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>N</mi><mi>c</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>g</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mi>W</mi><mn>4</mn></msubsup></mrow><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>H</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>v</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mfrac><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub><msup><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mn>2</mn></msup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>π</mi></mfrac><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mi>W</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msubsup><mi>d</mi><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><msup><mi>W</mi><mo>*</mo></msup><mo>→</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi/><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow></mrow></msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msubsup><mi>d</mi><mrow><mi>P</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>→</mo><mrow><mi>W</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>W</mi><mo>*</mo></msup></mrow></mrow></msubsup><mpadded width="+1.7pt"><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℱ</mi></mpadded><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
where ${\cal F}$, evaluated from the spin sum and the trace, is
\begin{eqnarray} 
 {\cal F} &=& \frac{16}{m_W^4}\left[ 
 2 m_{W}^2 (p_2.p_3)(p_2.p_4) + 4 m_W^2(k.p_3)(k.p_4)
 -2 m_W^2 m_{12}^2 (p_3.p_4)-2 (k.p_2)(k.p_3)(p_2.p_4) 
 \right. \nonumber\\
 && \left. 
 - 2 (k.p_2)(k.p_4)(p_2.p_3) +  2 (k.p_2)^2(p_3.p_4) +m_{12}^4 (p_3.p_4) 
 -2 m_{12}^2 (k.p_3)(k.p_4)
 \right.\nonumber\\
 && 
 \left. + 2 m_{W}^{-2}  (k.p_2)^2(k.p_3)(k.p_4) -m_{W}^{-2} m_{12}^2 (p_3.p_4)(k.p_2)^2 + m_W^4 (p_4.p_3)\right]\,. 
\end{eqnarray}

A comparison of our method, where the integration is done numerically by {\tt Mathematica} \cite{Mathematica}, and 
the result from {\tt CalcHEP v3.6.25} \cite{calchep}, is shown in Table 1. The typical 
uncertainty in the evaluation of the decay width through Monte Carlo sampling is about 10\%, 
and our method is in complete agreement.

\subsection{$H\to t {\overline}{t}^*$, ${\overline}{t}^*\to  {\overline}{b} W^-$}

\begin{figure}[h!]
\begin{center}
\includegraphics[width=8cm]{h_tbw.pdf}
\end{center}
\caption{Feynman diagram for $H\to t {\overline}{t}^*$, ${\overline}{t}^*\to {\overline}{b} W^-$.
}
\label{fig:htt}
\end{figure}


This is an analogous case with a fictitious heavy Higgs boson and involving an off-shell fermion. The Feynman 
diagram, including the spin and momentum labels, is shown in Fig.\ \ref{fig:htt}. Thus
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Gamma(H\to t{\overline{}}{b}W)=\frac{1}{m_{H}}\int\frac{1}{\pi}\frac{dm_{12}^%
{2}}{(m_{12}^{2}-m_{t}^{2})^{2}}{\rm Tr}\left[\tilde{\Gamma}(H\to t{\overline{%
}}{t}^{*})\tilde{\Gamma}({\overline{}}{t}^{*}\to{\overline{}}{b}W)\right]\,." display="block"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>t</mi><mover accent="true"><mi/><mo>¯</mo></mover><mi>b</mi><mi>W</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>H</mi></msub></mfrac><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>π</mi></mfrac><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac><mi>Tr</mi><mrow><mo>[</mo><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>t</mi><mover accent="true"><mi/><mo>¯</mo></mover><msup><mi>t</mi><mo>*</mo></msup><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mover accent="true"><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mover accent="true"><mi/><mo>¯</mo></mover><msup><mi>t</mi><mo>*</mo></msup><mo>→</mo><mover accent="true"><mi/><mo>¯</mo></mover><mi>b</mi><mi>W</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo rspace="4.2pt">]</mo></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Gamma(H\rightarrow t{\overline{}}{b}W)=\Big{(}\frac{1}{4m_{H}}\Big{)}\frac{g^%
{4}m_{t}^{2}N_{c}|V_{tb}|^{2}}{32m_{W}^{2}}\int\left[\frac{1}{\pi}\left(\frac{%
dm_{12}^{2}}{(m_{12}^{2}-m_{t}^{2})^{2}}\right)\right]\int d_{ps}^{H%
\rightarrow t{\overline{}}{t}^{*}}\int d_{ps}^{{\overline{}}{t}^{*}\rightarrow%
{\overline{}}{b}W}\mathcal{F}," display="block"><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Γ</mi><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>H</mi><mo>→</mo><mi>t</mi><mover accent="true"><mi/><mo>¯</mo></mover><mi>b</mi><mi>W</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">(</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>m</mi><mi>H</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac><mo maxsize="160%" minsize="160%">)</mo></mrow><mfrac><mrow><msup><mi>g</mi><mn>4</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>N</mi><mi>c</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>b</mi></mrow></msub><mo stretchy="false">|</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow><mn>32</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mi>W</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow></mfrac><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mo>[</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>π</mi></mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><msup><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msubsup><mi>m</mi><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></mfrac><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>]</mo></mrow><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msubsup><mi>d</mi><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>→</mo><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi/><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>t</mi><mo>*</mo></msup></mrow></mrow></msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><msubsup><mi>d</mi><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>s</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi/><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>t</mi><mo>*</mo></msup></mrow><mo>→</mo><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi/><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mi>b</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>W</mi></mrow></mrow></msubsup><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℱ</mi><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
One can further simplify the decay width after writing the phase spaces explicitly. 
The similar decay processes are discussed in \cite{Singh:1969ys,Kumar:1970cr,Skrzypek:1999td}. One can easily accommodate the interfering contribution by adding an extra term (if there is any), $\Gamma(l_1 \leftrightarrow l_3, l_2 \leftrightarrow l_4)$, in the above equation.  


\section{Conclusions}

 In this paper we have proposed an algorithm to treat the $n$-body phase space analytically,
 as a product of several virtual 2-body phase spaces. Compared to the standard Monte Carlo sampling, 
 this method is not only time-saving, particularly when a huge number of events are to be generated, 
 but also have comparable or even better accuracy. We have discussed the algorithm with several examples 
 involving off-shell scalars, fermions, and gauge bosons, and cross-checked our results with those available 
 in the literature or with standard software like {\tt CalcHEP}.  
 Implementation of this algorithm in an easy-to-use software is also under progress.
